questions.text: A patient has mental retardation, seizures, thrombotic state, amino acid metabolism disorder, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The clinical presentation, including mental retardation, seizures, a thrombotic state, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis, is characteristic of homocystinuria.

 

Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS), an enzyme involved in methionine metabolism. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of homocysteine, which can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurodevelopmental issues, skeletal abnormalities, and vascular complications.

 

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is crucial in the management of homocystinuria, as it is a cofactor for CBS. Supplementation with vitamin B6 can enhance the activity of the residual enzyme, helping to reduce homocysteine levels in responsive patients, thus mitigating the symptoms and reducing the risk of complications such as thrombosis.

 

Note –

 

The causes of ectopia lentis include several conditions, such as Marfan's syndrome, homocystinuria, Weill-Marchesani syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. These are important to remember when identifying the underlying cause of lens dislocation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 is also involved in homocysteine metabolism, deficiencies in B12 are not directly related to the presentation seen in homocystinuria. B12 supplementation is more relevant to other conditions such as pernicious anemia or when correcting elevated homocysteine due to B12 deficiency, but it is not the primary treatment for homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is not involved in the metabolic pathway of homocysteine. It plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism and is associated with conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi but not with homocystinuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is not directly related to the symptoms of homocystinuria or the management of this disorder. It is mainly involved in energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homocystinuria is characterized by ectopia lentis, thrombotic state, mental retardation, and seizures, among other features. Vitamin B6 supplementation is essential in managing this condition by aiding the function of the deficient enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

  • Epigenetics refers to the study of heritable changes in gene expression or cellular phenotype that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation, can modify gene expression by adding or removing chemical marks on DNA or histone proteins, thereby influencing how genes are activated or silenced. These changes can be passed from one generation of cells to the next, making them heritable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence itself. They can result in alterations to the genetic code, potentially leading to changes in gene expression. Mutations are genetic changes and do not fall under the category of epigenetic modifications, which involve changes to gene expression without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation involves the rearrangement of genetic material between non-homologous chromosomes. It can lead to changes in gene positioning but is not primarily associated with epigenetic modifications like methylation and acetylation.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversion is a type of chromosomal rearrangement where a segment of a chromosome is reversed. Similar to translocation, it can result in changes in gene positioning but is not directly related to epigenetic modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics has been defined and today is generally accepted as ‘‘the study of changes in gene function that are mitotically and/or meiotically heritable and that do not entail a change in DNA sequence.

 

Epigenetic modification of core histones (acetylation of specific lysine residues) facilitates an open structure and permits access to transcription factors for interaction with DNA. On the other hand, methylation at the CG sequence of the promoters transcriptionally inactivates chromatin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Information Communication Technology based Surveillance system for TB patients under National TB Elimination Program? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nikshay

 

Nikshay is an online software platform used in India for the surveillance of tuberculosis (TB) patients under the National TB Elimination Program. This Information and Communication Technology (ICT)-based system connects all the DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) clinics across the country to a central server managed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. It allows for real-time data generation and monitoring, providing critical insights into cure rates, incidences of multi-drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), treatment failures, relapses, and other important metrics. The system's comprehensive data collection capabilities make it an essential tool in the fight against TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DOTS: DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) is a strategy rather than a surveillance system. It involves healthcare workers observing patients take their TB medication to ensure compliance, but it is not a technological platform like Nikshay.

 

Option B. DOTS-99: DOTS-99 is an ICT-based adherence system, not a surveillance system. It is designed to ensure patients adhere to their TB treatment regimen. After taking their medication, patients give a missed call to a toll-free number using their registered mobile number. This system is effective in tracking medication adherence but does not provide the comprehensive surveillance and data management features of Nikshay.

 

Option D. Nischay: "Nischay" is not related to TB surveillance or management. This option does not pertain to any ICT-based system for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay is the ICT-based surveillance system used for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program in India. It enables real-time data collection and monitoring of TB cases across the country.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is secreted by which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Liver
b. Kidney
c. Spleen
d. Heart
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a, b

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) is a hormone responsible for stimulating the production of red blood cells in the bone marrow. The primary source of erythropoietin in the human body is the kidney, which accounts for about 90% of its production. The liver contributes approximately 10% of erythropoietin production.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

a. Liver: The liver produces erythropoietin mainly during fetal development, and its contribution decreases postnatally, although it continues to produce a small amount in adults.

 

b. Kidney: Erythropoietin is mainly produced by interstitial fibroblast-like cells located in the renal cortex, particularly near the proximal convoluted tubules. The production of EPO in the kidneys is primarily regulated by oxygen levels; hypoxia (low oxygen levels) stimulates its secretion.

 

The spleen and heart are not known sources of erythropoietin production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option c & d: Neither the spleen nor the heart produce erythropoietin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys (90%) and to a lesser extent by the liver (10%). These organs are the main sources of erythropoietin in the human body, with the kidneys playing a dominant role in its regulation and production in response to hypoxia.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertriglyceridemia: Elevated triglyceride levels are a criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicate dyslipidemia.

 

Option C. Central Obesity: Defined by waist circumference, this is a key criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicates visceral fat accumulation.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae binds with which receptors in the intestine? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, a disease characterized by severe watery diarrhea, often referred to as "rice water stools." The pathogenesis of cholera involves the cholera toxin, which plays a critical role in the disease process.

 

Upon ingestion of contaminated food or water, Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin in the intestinal lumen. The cholera toxin (2 subunits – A & B) does not enter the intestinal cells directly; instead, it binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of the intestinal epithelial cells. This binding facilitates the entry of the toxin into the cells.

 

Once inside the cell, the cholera toxin activates the enzyme adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP levels cause the inhibition of sodium absorption and an increase in chloride and water secretion into the intestinal lumen. This results in the characteristic watery diarrhea of cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. GM3: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option D. GM4: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP and resulting in watery diarrhea.

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged with fluid in the pelvic cavity (the black spaces seen in between the ovaries)
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space.
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections.
    • Multiple enlarged follicles are arranged in a necklace pattern in bilateral ovaries.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins are stopped in that cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: Enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy, not related to the provided scenario or ultrasound findings.

 

Option C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, but given the history and the ultrasound image, OHSS is the more appropriate answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OHSS is characterized by multiple enlarged ovarian follicles and fluid accumulation in the pelvic cavity, often occurring after exogenous gonadotropin administration in infertility treatments.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

questions.text: In PALS ABCDE all pairs are matched correctly except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D for dehydration

 

All pairs are correctly matched except D for dehydration.

 

Here it Should be D for disability

 

In Pediatric Basic and Advanced Life Support (PALS) mnemonic “ABCDE” stands for as follow -

 

A - Airway

B - Breathing

C - Circulation

D - Disability

E - Exposure

 

First, life-threatening airway problems are assessed and treated; second, life-threatening breathing problems are assessed and treated; and so on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PALS, the "D" in the ABCDE mnemonic stands for Disability, which involves assessing the child’s neurological status.

questions.text: A patient suffered from severe chest pain and expired. Which of the following is the likely age of infarct from the image of the cardiac biopsy shown here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 day

 

The cardiac biopsy image shows significant neutrophilic infiltration, which is a hallmark of early myocardial infarction.

 

 Neutrophilic infiltration in myocardial tissue occurs in two phases: early (within 24 hours) and late (after 24 hours).

 

In the early phase, neutrophils begin to infiltrate the infarcted tissue within the first 24 hours, but their numbers are relatively low. By the second and third days, neutrophil infiltration becomes more pronounced as the body attempts to clear the dead tissue. However, after 72 hours, neutrophils start to be replaced by macrophages. In this question, the presence of numerous neutrophils indicates that the infarct age is close to 1 day, as significant neutrophil accumulation typically peaks around 24 to 48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3-4 days: By this time, neutrophils are starting to be replaced by macrophages, which are responsible for further cleanup and early stages of healing. Therefore, extensive neutrophilic infiltration would not be seen at this stage.

 

Option C. 7-10 days: At this point, granulation tissue is starting to form, and macrophages predominate the area. Neutrophils would not be the primary cells observed, making this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. 2-3 weeks: By 2-3 weeks, granulation tissue is well established, and the repair process is progressing toward fibrosis. Neutrophils would not be present in large numbers at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brisk neutrophilic infiltration is a characteristic finding in myocardial tissue within the first 24 hours of infarction. The peak of neutrophil presence occurs around the second and third days, followed by the transition to macrophages.

choices.text: Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presents to the emergency department with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and confusion. On examination, the child appears dehydrated and is breathing rapidly. Laboratory tests reveal a blood glucose level of 400 mg/dl and blood gas analysis is indicative of acidosis. Initial treatment with intravenous fluids has been started. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is an acute, life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus that typically requires IV fluids and insulin administration to correct hyperglycemia and halt ketogenesis. According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour. 

Other options:

Option B. Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: According to new guidelines, bolus dose of insulin is not used for treatment of DKA particularly in children as it increases the risk of cerebral edema in many children.

 

Option A. Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin infusion is an essential part of DKA management, according to new guidelines, it's typically given one hour after the adminsitration of IV fluids.

 

Option D. Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration: This would not address the hyperglycemia and ketosis and is therefore inadequate for the treatment of DKA.

 

Educational Objective:

According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Proton

 

The Bragg peak effect is a phenomenon seen with proton therapy, where there is a sharp increase in radiation dose deposition at a specific depth, followed by a rapid decrease. This makes proton therapy particularly effective for targeting tumors with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: X-rays do not exhibit the Bragg peak; they deposit radiation relatively uniformly along their path, leading to more widespread tissue damage.

 

Option C. Neutron: Neutrons, while used in certain types of radiation therapy, do not exhibit a Bragg peak. Their interactions are different, primarily involving nuclear reactions.

 

Option D. Electron: Electrons do have a distinct depth-dose distribution, which includes a peak dose at a certain depth, but it is not as sharp or pronounced as the Bragg peak seen with protons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proton beam therapy characteristics:

 

  • It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues.
  • Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature.
  • Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker for myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Ischemia-modified albumin (IMA) is considered one of the earliest markers for myocardial infarction (MI). It can be detected in the blood within minutes of ischemia and before any significant myocardial necrosis occurs.

 

The novelty of IMA lies in its ability to indicate ischemia even before traditional markers like CK-MB or Troponin I rise, making it particularly useful in the early diagnosis of MI. Its primary utility, however, is in its negative predictive value—if IMA levels are normal, it's more likely that the patient is not experiencing an MI.

 

Additionally,

 

Heart Fatty Acid Binding Protein (H-FABP), one more novel early marker is noted for its rapid response following myocardial injury. It can be detected early in the blood after the onset of a heart attack, making it a valuable tool for early diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: CK-MB is a marker of myocardial injury that typically rises within 3-4 hours after the onset of infarction.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase 1 (LDH 1): LDH 1 is a late marker of myocardial infarction, typically rising 24-48 hours after the onset.

 

Note - LDH reacts with Triphenyl Tetrazole Chloride dye, which is used to visually differentiate between normal and infarcted cardiac tissue during diagnostic procedures. In the presence of this dye, normal cardiac tissue produces a big red color, while infarcted areas show a yellowish appearance. This color differentiation helps in identifying and assessing the extent of myocardial damage.

 

Option C. Cardiac Troponin I: Cardiac Troponins, especially Troponin I, are highly specific for myocardial injury and are the gold standard for diagnosing MI. However, they typically rise within 4-6 hours after the onset, making them less useful as the earliest marker compared to IMA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin (IMA) is an early biomarker for myocardial infarction, detectable shortly after ischemia begins, and is particularly valuable for its ability to rule out MI when levels are normal.

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.text: During disaster management, triage is conducted to ensure proper treatment of casualties. What are the accurate aspects of the triage process carried out at the site of the disaster? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Moribund patients receive the lowest priority

 

In Triage, these patients are given different color coding as mentioned below –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In disaster triage, moribund patients receive the lowest priority, allowing medical resources to be focused on patients with a higher chance of survival.

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

questions.text: Which of the following is not glucogenic?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl coenzyme A

 

  • Acetyl CoA is not glucogenic. It enters the citric acid cycle (Kreb's cycle) for energy production and cannot be directly converted into glucose. It is primarily used for energy generation in the form of ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxaloacetate: Oxaloacetate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into glucose through a series of enzymatic reactions in the gluconeogenesis pathway. This makes it a precursor for glucose synthesis.

 

Option C. Lactate: Lactate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into pyruvate in the Cori cycle, and pyruvate can then be used in gluconeogenesis to produce glucose.

 

Option D. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a glucogenic compound. It serves as a central molecule in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, making it a key intermediate in the conversion of various substrates into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA is not a glucogenic compound as it cannot be directly converted into glucose, unlike oxaloacetate, lactate, and pyruvate, which are glucogenic and contribute to glucose synthesis.

 

Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)                                                                                     

  1. Pyruvate (3C)
  2. Lactate (3C)                                                              
  3. Propionic acid (3C)
  4. Glycerol (3C)                                                       
  5. Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids)
  6. Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids
  7. Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.
It is a water-soluble vitamin.
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to Vitamin K deficiency

 

Option C: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.

 

  • True. Prolonged use of certain antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut flora responsible for synthesizing vitamin K. This disruption can lead to a deficiency in vitamin K, which is essential for blood clotting.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.

 

  • False. Vitamin K deficiency does not lead to hypercoagulability. Instead, it leads to hypocoagulability, which means impaired blood clotting. Vitamin K is essential for the activation of clotting factors in the blood, and its deficiency can result in bleeding disorders, not excessive blood clotting.

 

Option B. It is a water-soluble vitamin.

 

  • False. Vitamin K is not a water-soluble vitamin; it is a fat-soluble vitamin. Fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamins A, D, E, and K, are absorbed with dietary fats and are stored in the body's fatty tissues.

 

Option D. Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

 

  • Partially true. While menaquinone (vitamin K2) is a form of vitamin K, the primary dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables is phylloquinone (vitamin K1). Both forms of vitamin K are essential for various biological functions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin.

 

Sources of vitamin K:

 

  • Green leafy vegetables (Phylloquinone/ Vitamin K1)
  • Synthesis by intestinal bacteria (Menaquinones/Vitamin K2)
  • Menadione is synthetic compound metabolized to phylloquinone.

 

In normal adult dietary deficiency seldom occurs since the intestinal bacterial synthesis is sufficient to meet the needs of the body. However, deficiency can occur in conditions of malabsorption of lipids due to obstructive jaundice, chronic pancreatitis, sprue, etc.

 

Prolonged antibiotic therapy and gastrointestinal infections with diarrhea will destroy the bacterial flora and can also lead to vitamin K deficiency.

 

Vitamin K is necessary for coagulation. Factors dependent on vitamin K are Factor II (prothrombin); Factor VII (SPCA); Factor IX (Christmas factor); Factor X (Stuart Power factor) therefore deficiency will to lead to bleeding disorders.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Spermatogonia: These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.

 

Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with stable vitals and ECG showing PSVT. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

     

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in a stable child begins with pharmacological intervention rather than immediate cardioversion. Adenosine is the drug of choice for PSVT due to its ability to temporarily block the atrioventricular node, effectively terminating the arrhythmia.

 

The initial dose of adenosine recommended is 0.1 mg/kg given as a rapid IV bolus over 1-3 seconds. If there is no response, subsequent doses can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg, and if necessary, 0.3 mg/kg can be administered under monitored conditions. Rapid bolus administration is essential, followed by a 5-10 ml of saline flush to ensure the drug reaches systemic circulation quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardioversion: Cardioversion is typically reserved for cases where the patient is unstable or when pharmacological management fails. In a stable patient, the initial approach is to use adenosine to terminate the PSVT without the need for electrical intervention.

 

Option B. Adenosine 0.3 mg per kg: While this dosage of adenosine can be used if initial doses do not work, it is not the starting dose. The initial dose should be lower, at 0.1 mg/kg, to minimize potential adverse effects.

 

Option C. Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg: This dose of adenosine is appropriate for a second attempt if the initial dose (0.1 mg/kg) does not resolve the PSVT. It is not the first-line dose but can be escalated to after the initial dose fails.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable PSVT in children, adenosine is the first-line treatment, starting at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg. If this dose is ineffective, the dose may be escalated in subsequent attempts.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns. It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain). Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arnold chiari malformation: Arnold chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the most commonest cause of ventriculomegaly

 

Option B. Dandy walker malformation: Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C. Arachnoid villi malformation: Arachnoid villi malformation is not the most commonest cause

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with a history of chronic and recurrent itchy flexural lesions, considering his family history of asthma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

 

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify atopic dermatitis as a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the EEG shown below: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

The EEG provided shows a pattern that mimics an awake state, which is indicative of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is characterized by specific EEG, EOG (electro-oculogram), and EMG (electromyogram) patterns:

 

  1. EEG (Electroencephalogram): During REM sleep, the EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency activity that resembles the awake state. This is in contrast to the high amplitude, low-frequency waves seen in NREM (Non-Rapid Eye Movement) sleep stages.
  2. EOG (Electro-oculogram): The EOG shows rapid eye movements, which are characteristic of REM sleep. These movements are visible as sharp spikes or fluctuations in the EOG tracing.
  3. EMG (Electromyogram): The EMG shows muscle atonia or paralysis, which is another hallmark of REM sleep. This paralysis prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams. Only the diaphragm and extraocular muscles remain active during REM sleep.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NREM1: This is the lightest stage of sleep, characterized by a transition from wakefulness to sleep. The EEG shows a mix of alpha and theta waves, with some slow eye movements, but it does not resemble the awake state as closely as REM sleep does.

 

Option B. NREM2: This stage is marked by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG. It is a deeper stage of sleep than NREM1 but does not show the rapid eye movements or muscle atonia seen in REM sleep.

 

Option C. NREM3: Also known as slow-wave sleep (SWS), this stage is characterized by high amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. It is the deepest stage of NREM sleep and does not resemble the awake state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by EEG patterns similar to wakefulness, rapid eye movements on EOG, and muscle atonia on EMG.

choices.text: Mono-unsaturated fatty acids
Poly-unsaturated fatty acids

questions.text: Which require maximum energy for assimilation? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Option A. Proteins:

  • Proteins are complex macromolecules consisting of amino acids.
  • They require a significant amount of energy for assimilation because the body needs to break them down into individual amino acids, which are then used for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbohydrates:

  • Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy for the body.
  • They are relatively easy to assimilate as they are broken down into glucose, which can be readily used for energy.

 

Option C. Mono-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Mono-unsaturated fatty acids are a type of dietary fat found in foods like olive oil and avocados.
  • They require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins because they can be broken down relatively easily and used for energy or stored as fat.

 

Option D. Poly-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Poly-unsaturated fatty acids, such as omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential fats found in certain foods.
  • Similar to mono-unsaturated fatty acids, they require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteins require the maximum energy for assimilation among the options listed, as they need to be broken down into individual amino acids for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prevented by folic acid supplementation in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy significantly reduces the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. Adequate folic acid intake is crucial during the early stages of pregnancy, often before a woman even knows she is pregnant, which is why supplementation is recommended for all women of childbearing age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help in the prevention of certain types of anemia, such as megaloblastic anemia, it is not the primary preventive measure for anemia during pregnancy, which is more commonly addressed with iron supplementation.

 

Option B. Preeclampsia: Preeclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and damage to other organ systems. There is no strong evidence that folic acid supplementation alone can prevent preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy. Folic acid supplementation is not known to prevent gestational diabetes; its primary preventive role is in reducing the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition. [NEET PG  2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: Calculate the mid parental height of a male patient with father height 183 cm and mother height 175 cm? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 185.5

 

The mid-parental height (MPH) is a method used to estimate the potential adult height of a child based on the heights of the parents.

 

Formula:

 

Using the given heights:

 

  • Father's height = 183 cm
  • Mother's height = 175 cm
  • MPH = [(183+175)/2] + 6.5 = 185.5

 

Therefore, the mid-parental height is 185.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To calculate the mid-parental height for a male child, use the formula:

 

(Father’s height+Mother’s height)/2+6.5 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab
 

Alirocumab and Evolocumab are PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors. These works by inhibiting the PCSK9 enzyme which is responsible for degradation of LDL receptors in the liver. Therefore, these drugs lead to an increased number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on liver cells and a subsequent decrease in LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. PCSK9 inhibitors are used for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease and have not adequately responded to statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, which leads to a reduction in the total amount of cholesterol presented to the liver. It does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Option C. Bempedoic Acid: Bempedoic acid is a relatively new cholesterol-lowering medication. It inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, but it is not a PCSK9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Clofibrate: Clofibrate is a fibrate used to lower lipid levels, particularly triglycerides. It works by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and cause wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: A man habitually consumes coffee before bedtime and claims difficulty in sleep during night. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness

 

Caffeine is a stimulant that is commonly consumed to reduce fatigue and increase alertness. Its primary mechanism of action in promoting wakefulness is through blocking the action of adenosine, a neurotransmitter in the brain that promotes sleep and relaxation by binding to adenosine receptors. Normally, when adenosine binds to its receptors, it leads to drowsiness and a decrease in nerve cell activity. Caffeine, due to its structural similarity to adenosine, competes for these receptors but does not activate them. Instead, it blocks the action of adenosine, preventing the onset of sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in physiological responses to stress and panic, and it is active during REM sleep to help regulate wakefulness. However, caffeine does not directly activate the locus coeruleus to cause wakefulness; instead, its wakefulness-promoting effect is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade.

 

Option C. No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep: This statement is incorrect because caffeine does play a significant role in maintaining wakefulness even if consumed an hour before sleep. Caffeine has a half-life of about 5-6 hours, meaning it remains active in the system for several hours after consumption, potentially leading to difficulty falling asleep.

 

Option D. Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in wakefulness, but caffeine does not exert its wakefulness-promoting effects through histamine release. The primary mechanism is through blocking adenosine receptors, not activating histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, thereby preventing the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine.

questions.text: A patient of sickle cell anemia developed aplastic crisis after a viral infection. The agent causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 is known for its predilection for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, which it infects and destroys. This leads to a transient halt in red blood cell production, which can precipitate an aplastic crisis, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders like sickle cell anemia. The virus effectively shuts down erythropoiesis (red blood cell production), causing a significant drop in hemoglobin levels and resulting in severe anemia.

 

Patients with sickle cell anemia are particularly susceptible to this type of crisis because they already have a high rate of red blood cell turnover due to the intrinsic hemolysis caused by their abnormal hemoglobin. When Parvovirus B19 infection superimposes on this condition, the cessation of red cell production can lead to a profound aplastic crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause various infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not known to specifically cause aplastic crises or target red blood cell production.

 

Option B. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with infectious mononucleosis and can affect the lymphoid tissue but does not directly cause aplastic crisis by targeting red blood cell production.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): HBV primarily affects the liver, causing hepatitis, and does not have a known mechanism of inducing aplastic crisis by directly affecting the bone marrow's red blood cell production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the primary viral agent responsible for causing aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia due to its affinity for and destruction of erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The centromeric pattern is characterized by distinct dots in the nucleus, corresponding to centromeres during cell division. This pattern is associated with anti-centromere antibodies (ACA), commonly seen in limited cutaneous scleroderma (CREST syndrome). ACA antibody is  correlate with pulmonary hypertension seen in patients with limited disease. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogenous: Diffuse staining of the nucleus, seen with anti-ds DNA antibodies or anti-histone antibodies.
 

Option C. Speckled: Numerous fine or coarse speckles, a kind of quite nonspecific, associated with various antibodies such as anti-SEL70, anti-JOAN, and anti-SMITH antibodies, etc
 

Option D. Nucleolar: Prominent nucleolar staining, quite nonspecific, seen with Anti-PM-Scl antibody, an overlap antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centromeric pattern in ANA staining is associated with anti-centromere antibodies and limited scleroderma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:
